text: [Applause] all right thanks thank you for um
choosing to join my talk here today um my name is marit V and I'm here to talk
to you about keeping your dependencies in check so usually I start with a question
to make sure we're on the same page page and I ask who uses open- Source software in their projects at work or at home and
all of the hands go go up so just to check is there anyone who doesn't use open- Source software don't be
shy okay so all of us so good we we we're starting on the right page so open
source is great because you know it allows you to
use a bunch of functionality without having to write it yourself so you can use your application
Frameworks testing Frameworks all kinds of tools without having to write them
yourselves so we can focus on delivering business value for the company that we
work for but there are downsides for the dependencies that we
declare they also use dependencies so instead of just the dependencies that we
declare we are pulling in transitive dependencies who might even have more transitive dependenc IES and you know
they lead to can lead to all kinds of trouble they'll make your binaries bigger because you're pulling in a bunch
of stuff um if you're really lucky or unlucky there will be clashes between
different transitive dependencies that you have to resolve and of course any of those dependencies that
you declare or the ones that they pull in can contain
vulnerabilities if if you're a Java developer who is a Java
developer okay for the rest of you bear with us so um if you're a Java developer
you'll remember what happened in December of 2021 even the people nodding up front
yes so thank you Liz what happened was
people were getting ready for the holidays and log for Shell was um
disclosed and in fact literally at my previous uh job I had a coworker who is
a log forj maintainer he was literally planning to go on holiday when this
vulnerability was disclosed and instead worked 20 22-hour days to fix it so this
is your cue to thank an open source maintainer today um so what that meant for the rest
of us was urgently updating all of our applications in some cases even
twice um because after the first vulnerability was um fixed it turned out
there were several others that also needed to be fixed um and I was working at an online retail platform at the time
where teams were responsible for uh several microservices so it meant updating literally several applications
and then again after the second uh cves were fixed um which was nice
because in March of the next year we got to do it again when when spring for
Shell uh dropped but the upside is we had just gotten a lot of practice
urgently deploying everything some even on a Friday as recommended by by charity
um at honeycomb so um you know we got we got our practice in in urgently deploying
our applications but to be fair I pref prer my software development to be a
little more boring than that so we know
that there are pros and cons to using external dependencies uh so first I want
to look at what to look for when um and and how to what to look for when selecting dependencies and and why
that's important there are I've seen two extremes of dealing with this one is
literally like okay we're not using any external dependencies or you know as little as we can possibly get away with
and you end up writing a lot of stuff yourself which is great because then you have full control of it but you're going
to slow down your software development and delivering your business value on
the other hand you don't want to be like this and just you know import any dependency I have a problem I'll go look
on stack Overflow or ask chat GPT for the solution it suggests to import this
dependency and all of my problems will magically go away let's just do that and not think about it also not
great so let's start by considering whether we need the dependencies that
we're using preferably before we start using it but if you're in a situation
where you currently have a bunch of dependencies maybe take the time occasionally to re-evaluate whether you
still want them whether these are still the ones that you want and whether you still need them to solve a particular
particular problem so what are some of the things that you want to think about
first you want to think about is this librar or framework a good fit for the
problem that I have both in terms of is it the right solution for this problem
but also in terms of is the relative size of this framework or Library
relative to the size of my problem or am I using there's a Dutch expression using a cannon to shoot a mosquito
you know if it's too much for your small problem maybe there's a better solution out there you want to consider whether this
um dependency is wellmaintained and that means um are there frequent
releases are bugs fixed fairly quickly are there active maintainers are
there is there more than one active maintainer uh because there's an XKCD
for everyone some of you recognized it right away um there are lots of projects
that are maintained by one person who is doing a thankless job not getting any
appreciation for it um and what happens if that person for whatever reason can
no longer maintain this Library a term that's sometimes used here is the bus
Factor how many people can get hit by a bus before this project goes unmaintained and I really really don't
like this this term because I don't want to be thinking about people getting hit by buses so I've heard an alternative
term which I like a lot more which is called the lottery Factor how many people can win the
lottery and never have to code again if they don't want to you know some of us are idiots and prefer to do this even
for free um how many people can win the lottery and no longer have to write code before this Library goes
unmaintained um you might want to consider the community around a particular project are they friendly are
they welcoming are they um nice to people who start using it for the first time and ask a bunch of
newbie questions are they kind to people who report issues
or um create pool requests I was looking at a project recently that I was
thinking of maybe looking if into contributing to I looked at some issues
and they were arguing I'm like okay maybe not this project
so um consider whether you like using it we all have personal preferences we like
using certain tools and we dislike using other tools so you know we have
hopefully some flexibility into making our jobs more enjoyable if you can select the ones that you
like and uh think about the impact that a particular dependency will have on
your code base some dependencies are relatively small I'm thinking string
utils for example is fairly small you'll use it only in very specific places if
you ever decide you want to remove it uh because for example actual example you're moving from java to cotlin and
you're going to use extension functions instead you can easily remove it other
libraries for example if you're using lombok or a reactor will infect your
entire code base and they will be everywhere and removing it will be harder much like having dandelion in
your garden ask me how I know um and finally if you decide that you do want
to use a particular dependency make sure that you use a version that doesn't have any known
vulnerabilities um Jamie Coleman over at sonatype shared this uh website with me
they have an overview of the number of people who are still downloading that
particular version of log forj uh with the severe vulnerability and this is a

version I Look to update the slide um today and the numbers are still the

this with a newer version so where do we find this
information one place to look is Maven Central or uh nowadays sonatype will
redirect you to central.on type.com because they've been running Maven Central for a very long time and here
you can uh look for um packages in the in the jvm uh
ecosystem and you can find information about specific dependencies how to
import it to your project this is what it used to look like this is what it looks like
now so you can find how to import it to your project you can find additional
information um some metadata what license it uses um they give a safety rating here
and you can go to the um OSS IND index to see whether a particular version has

course um Jackson datab bind is a serialization deserialization library for those that
are not familiar which is notorious for having interesting security uh problems
so they tend to have known vulnerabilities that are then fixed
Etc not saying you shouldn't use it just uh something to be aware of and

the type of license that it uses how to imported to your uh package and also a

directly to uh the code you can find a lot of information uh on GitHub or
wherever the uh project is hosted of course you can look at the actual code if that's something that

merged by how many people Etc and you can have a look at contributors which will uh track contributions by
contributor over time so you can see that uh Jackson datab bind for example is maintained pretty much by only one
person which is kind of scary um so that is you know slightly
other rant but you know if more people could get involved in open source that would be great so overall we know that
maintaining our dependencies is important but most developers would much rather be
doing something else right so we're going to look at some of

updates the next set of tools that you can use are are Bots that can do automatic PRS for you I'll focus on the

but I think all of these also work for other languages the first one is dependabot uh
dependabot is GitHub native they acquired it in 2000 something I forget um and it
offers several features one is alerts so it it will give you an alert if you're using vulnerable versions but without
doing anything the second is security updates so if you're using a dependency that has uh known vulnerabilities it
will create a PR to update that uh dependency for you and the last one is version updates so if there's a new
version not necessarily because of security uh reasons you can update to that because it's GitHub native you can
enable it from the settings if you go to code security and Analysis you can
enable either the alerts and or the security updates um and you also can have a
dependency graph which will show you all of the information so it used to be that it
highlighted in yellow that you had known vulnerabilities it looks like it no
longer does that but I've been doing this talk for a year and turning it off and on and off and on again and none of
the Bots seem to really like that so um if you enable this on your repositories
it might look slightly different uh but the general idea will be the same so it
will give you information on which dependency it which dependencies it wants to update for
you um you can expand the the thing to
say uh to give you a little bit more information they used to give quite some information in the uh PRS that they
created but also it seems that they no longer do that so they're just saying okay I want to bump this version but not
necessarily providing you with information on why um and if you want to do the version
updates as well so there is a new version of this Library not necessarily for security reasons you need to add um
a yl file um also your regular reminder that yl sounds like yummer in Dutch
which is the word for too bad or unfortunate so um but anyway we use it for
configuration it has white space that has meaning which is all sorts of fun um and you need to specify the package

overwhelmed do you want it to automatically rebase or not um
Etc um it's GitHub native but you can also configure it to run on gitlab if
that's what you're using but you have other options the next option is renovate which is what we
used at my previous uh employer they also offer security updates and version
updates and they give you a project uh dashboard which shows you what you need to update for your particular um project
it's not GitHub native but there is a GitHub app I tried them all on GitHub because that was the easiest way for me
to try them um you need to add it to your account renovate uh by default
offers you the option to select only one repository to run it on so if you've never tried any of these Bots and you

a PR and once that's merged it will start doing its thing um you can uh as I said select all

other stuff that you're working on uh it does have an rule-based auto merge so for things that you know you want to

it has more options that is more fine grained than dependables the PRS provide more

support a bunch of pro of platforms including GitHub GI gitlab um and
more the last option is Sneak open source which also offers security
updates and version updates but they have uh some additional features that can be really nice uh one is that they
can test for vulnerabilities on incoming PRS which the other two don't so that's
nice because if someone tries to add a vulnerable dependency in between you know your weekly run uh you can catch

are slightly better looking than the renovate ones you can enable sneak via
their website um you can choose how to uh
integrate uh Set uh permissions so here you have the option between uh public and private or public repost but you

to have the option um yeah on whether you want to only

old uh known vulnerabilities uh separately from new incoming vulnerabilities you can do that you need

updates um it will create automatic PRS for you on your repository meaning that

Java effects and you can create your own migration and what it will do is it will

you want to uh if you still need to do these migrations the next tool I want to
discuss is error prone which is I think only for Java it's a static analysis tool to
catch common programming mistakes so not necessarily intended as a version
migration tool but it's intended to replace certain patterns in your code
with a different pattern uh you can use it running uh you can run it using uh Maven gradal or plugins for your uh IDE
so what it can do is it can find bug patterns in your code it can alert on
those just to let you know hey you're doing something you probably don't want to but it can also fix it and it uh

can also Define your own um and I know that at picnic um in
the Netherlands they have used this tool also to upgrade from for example Java 8 to Java 11 uh using certain patterns uh

to tell you about is open rewrite open rewrite is explicitly uh intended for

help you fix those um findings it has Java colon and groovy support because
